Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Persistence of Monoecy in Deep Time: An Integrated Biological and Paleontological Approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project integrates paleontology and evolutionary biology to investigate the evolution of sexual systems. The existence of so many methods of reproduction in the natural world remains difficult to explain. Contemporary theories assume that sexual reproduction should allow long term survival as the dispersal and recombination of genetic material provides a population of organisms with the ability to adapt to environmental change. Small freshwater crustaceans, or ?clam shrimp,? are ideal for the study of sexual system evolution as the group contains species that comprise males and females, species where females no longer exist and have been completely replaced by self-fertilizing hermaphrodites (with the ability to fertilize their own eggs) coexisting with males, and species with only self-fertilizing hermaphrodites. Using the otherwise inconspicuous ?clam shrimp? as a study group, it is possible to identify sex via carapace (shell) shape analysis techniques in both living and fossil populations. Once sexes are identified, we can deduce sexual system via sex ratio of the population.
This study aims to collect fossil data from worldwide repositories in order to provide, for the first time, empirical evidence to test established theories about the origination, duration and extinction of sexual systems over geologic timescales. We can then address the commonly held belief that unisexual systems represent an evolutionary ?dead end.? The results of this study will also provide a foundation for future research utilizing the fossil record to perform transformative studies into the evolution of mating systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

One of the most frustrating aspects of studying the evolution of
reproductive systems is that we have, to date, been unable to utilize
information locked within the fossil record to assess reproductive system
evolution in deep time. The focus of this research was to empirically test the following assumptions that have been an integral part of biological cannon for the past century: 1) lineages that primarily reproduce unisexually (i.e., with only one parent) will tend to go extinct more often and speciate less often than lineages that reproduce sexually, and (2) that transitional sexual systems (in this case androdioecy: males + self-fertilizing hermaphrodites) between complete hermaphroditism and obligate sexual outcrossing should be highly unstable and should not persist over long periods of time.

In this funded study we used the Spinicaudatan ‘clam shrimp’ as a model group to investigate the evolutionary dynamics of sexual systems over geologic time. This group of primitive branchiopod crustaceans is geographically widespread with a particularly good freshwater fossil record extending back 400Ma, to the Devonian period. Modern day clam shrimp are reproductively diverse, exhibiting dioecious (males + females),  hermaphroditic and androdioecious populations. The diversity and distribution of these reproductive systems raise interesting questions about the validity of long standing theories of reproductive system evolution.

In this project, we developed a mathematical methodology that allows us to detect subtle shape differences exhibited between the sexes in the shells of these clam shrimp. This shape analysis allows us to assess sex ratios of fossil assemblages, from which we can determine reproductive system. In this project, we visited six museums located all over the world (Russia, England, U.S.A., Argentina, China and Australia) to photograph 580 fossil clam shrimp.  From these photographs, we determined shape differences and assigned reproductive system to 47 fossil species. These data have allowed us, for the first time, the ability to determine reproductive systems from fossil species in a reproductively diverse lineage (in our case, clam shrimp).

Our developed methodology provides empirical measurements of reproductive system evolution for the very first time in a comprehensive integrated neontological and palaeontological approach. The complete absence of species with only one sex (i.e., "unisexuality") in the fossil clam shrimp studied so far supports the evolutionary theory that unisexuality (in this case, species that exclusively comprise self-fertilizing females) should be short lived and prone to extinction. On the other hand, the finding of sex ratios suggestive of androdioecy (30-35% males) in four fossil taxa in this study suggests that androdioecy is more stable than previously assumed and has evolved multiple times in this group in the geologic past.  

Although these data are still being analyzed, we can tentatively suggest that: (1) none of the 47 fossil species so far examined are unisexual, which agrees with the prediction that unisexual species should be rare because they both go extinct more often and are less likely to speciate than sexual species; and (2) androdioecy has been found in four of the 47 species so far examined, suggesting that this "transitional" reproductive system is more stable than theory predicts, at least in this group of crustaceans. As we finalize our data
analyses, we can more clearly address both of these predictions, and are
developing research papers that will present our findings.
